Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Three-Dimensional Simulations of Type Ia Supernovae: Constraining Models with Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-0709181/AST-0707704/AST-0708873/AST-0708855
Kohkhlov/Baron/Wang/Hoeflich

This project is a comprehensive theoretical analysis of thermonuclear Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia), which will account for any three-dimensional (3D) processes affecting SNe Ia explosions, and will provide a rigorous comparison of model predictions with existing and future high quality observations. The methods and techniques will be combined into the remote-access SNe Ia computational pipeline, which comprises sophisticated 3D simulation algorithms for fluid dynamics, nucleosynthesis, and radiation transport, as well as tools for the 3D analysis of SNe Ia data. SNe Ia are crucial for identifying the nature of dark energy, one of the most important problems facing modern science, because they serve as one of the most direct and precise distance indicators in the Universe. The results of this study will improve the cosmological calibration of these critical tools, by trying to understand what affects their status as standard candles, notably the different types of progenitor systems, deviations from spherical symmetry, and interaction with circumstellar matter. One important outcome will be a comprehensive set of observationally verified first-principles multidimensional explosion models of SNe Ia. Identifying physical correlations among predicted and observed signatures of SNe Ia will be crucial for improving the accuracy of their calibration.

This work is an exceptional platform for introducing students to cross-disciplinary and multi-field science, through the many areas involved in studying SNe Ia, such as numerical methods, large-scale hydrodynamics and radiation transport simulations, observations, and cosmological applications. Research results will be made available to the broad scientific community via the developed computational pipeline, and will be disseminated to the wider non-technical audience. The results will also benefit current and future ground- and space-based observing programs.

During the grant period two students from the University of Oklahoma
received PhDs working on the project: Bin Chen (now at Florida State
University), Soma De (finished postdoc at ETH Zurich, currently
searching for her next position). Brian Friesen (next position
NESAP Postdoctoral Fellow, NERSC/Berkeley National Lab) will receive
his PhD in May,
2015. Thirteen undergraduates worked on
related projects supported by a combination of project funds and funds
from the OU NSF REU site grant. These students represented nine
different higher learning institutions.


Forty five refereed papers were published and twenty five conference
contributions were presented.

At the University of Oklahoma the graduate student initiated group
Lunar Sooners was formed during the grant period. Brian Friesen and
Jeremy Lusk played a major role in Lunar Sooners. Lunar Sooners
performs a variety of outreach events including weekly star parties,
Science in action day, NASA OSGC, Star Parties in the Wichita
Mountains, visiting minority high schools in Oklahoma City, etc.

The major intellectual focus of the grant work was to continue to
probe the validity of the Chandrasekhar Mass model of the explosion of
Type Ia Supernovae. Type Ia Supernovae were used to discover the Dark
Energy, which led to the 2011 Nobel Prize in Physics. However, since
the progenitor system of Type Ia supernovae is unknown, the variation
of Type Ia supernovae with redshift is an important systematic
error. While the Chandrasekhar mass model has been the mainstay model
of a Type Ia supernova explosion in the last 3-5 years its validity
has been called into question particularly due to the more detailed
variation seen in individual Type Ia supernovae. Our group has worked
to show how this model may still be compatible with nearly all the
observations, but at the same time this work focuses just what the
model can and can not due, helping the scientific community to come to
a consensus about the nature of Type Ia supernova progenitor systems.

Simultaneously at the University of Oklahoma we have worked on the
improvement of our generalized stellar atmospheres code
PHOENIX. PHOENIX now runs in full 3D on over 100,000 computer cores in
parallel. We have added support for HDF5 which is used both for
speedup in collective I/O and for the output and ease of plotting many
intermediate quantities which allows us to perform detective work on
our results. Because radiative transfer is a highly non-linear
problem, it can be difficult to determine exactly what physical
phenomenon is causing what result and much of our work has focused on
teasing out exactly the cause and effect.
